text: We’ll hear arguments next in 72-486 and 488, Federal Power against Memphis Light and Texas Gas Transmission against Memphis Light consolidated.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
When you say the matter first came, you’re talking historically not about this particular proceeding?
That’s right, historically; it back was in 1956 or so.

May I ask you a couple of questions, does the record of the -- does the legislative history show why Congress is concern was limited to the impact of accelerated depreciation only with respect to public utilities?
No, it doesn’t -- not that I’m aware of.
I lost the point.
Accelerated tax depreciation is flow-through.
Well now that’s what I want to get.
There’s first the loss resulting to the increase that deduction --
Of tax remedy – because of the higher deduction there’s a lower tax remedy?

And then secondly, there’s a lower rates due to the flow-through which means that there’s less revenues to be taxed by the utilities -- have less revenues coming in to be taxed because the benefits are passed on in lower rates.
I see, so there’s a first of all a -- I see everything that lower rates to the consumers?
Lower rates to the consumer.
What was the company use?
Well, it said that it would use -- it sought permission to use normalization on the expansion property as well as on its existing property.
Thank you Mr. Huntington.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
May it please -- Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
What about the language on page 83 that your friend was discussing a bit ago?
Permits the change as to that property?
Well, isn’t that exactly what this tells us? Did you seem to suggest some doubt about what regulatory agency it would be?
Well, I'm just saying that this applies not only to Federal Power Commission, but it applies to all the regulatory [Voice Overlap].
No doubt that it similarly means Federal Power [voice overlap].
Oh, yes sir, yes sir it includes that.
But any change from the “flow-through” would of course be beneficial from the point of view of Congress’ concern at the time of the 1969 Act because it would serve to increase taxes?
But, yes Your Honor.
Because it would be change either the normalization or to start a straight-line?
But Your Honor, Congress have two concerns of equal value to it at that time.
Right.
The other concern was that we do it without creating widespread prompt substantial rate -- utility rate increase.
Mr. Chief Justice and members of the Court.
And so that the report really doesn’t speak to the act is finally passed [voice overlap]?

The report speaks to the Senate Bill then before them, the conference limit it and the Court of Appeals thought that was significant and I think it’s significant but you have to look at my brief for that point because I would really if I had a limited time I have like to go on to the exercise of power assuming they had any power.
Mr. Huntington.
I’d like to talk first about the power issue and then I have few remarks to say about the Commission’s exercise of discretion in this case.
